title: Planning notes for the pollock assessment in the EBS
text: Ongoing genetic studies determine relationship pollock NBS EBS, nearby GOA AI regions. 2019 BSAI GPT recommendation revisit evaluate treatment variance parameters within assessment, particular attention fixed. Efforts quantify pollock movement abundance along US-Russia EEZ boundary. Geostatistical analyses combined trawl acoustic data provide single time-series, statistically accounting overlap data, informing stock trends.

previous_headings: Example use of ebswp library for setting up a new model
title: Example on how to change and run a model
text: Now use process error tuned file fix vales “ssb” files
code: d1 <- read_dat("runs/dat/proctune1.dat") d2 <- read_dat("runs/dat/pm_ssb0.dat") d3            <- d2 d3$n_avo      <- d1$n_avo d3$ob_avo     <- d1$ob_avo d3$ob_avo_std <- d1$ob_avo_std d3$wt_avo     <- d1$wt_avo d3$yrs_avo    <- d1$yrs_avo  write_dat(output_file="runs/dat/pm_ssb0new.dat", indata=d3)  # Create directory and copy key files dir.create("runs/ssb0") file.copy("runs/ssb0_origProcTune/control.dat","runs/ssb0/",overwrite = TRUE) file.copy("runs/avon2/compweights.ctl","runs/ssb0/",overwrite = TRUE) file.remove("runs/ssb0/pm") file.symlink("../../src/pm","runs/ssb0/pm") # Read pm.dat, then write (e.g.,)   pm.dat<-read_table("runs/ProcTune/pm.dat",col_names=FALSE) # Add some description of the rows...   row.names(pm.dat) <- c("Desc","main","sel","ctl","altFmsy","cov","wtage","cpue","temp","q")   pm.dat   pm.dat[1,] <- "Updated_SSB0_to_proctune1"   pm.dat[2,] <- "../dat/pm_ssb0new.dat"   writeLines(as.character(pm.dat$X1),"runs/ssb0/pm.dat")

previous_headings: Example use of ebswp library for setting up a new model
title: Example on how to change and run a model
code: d1 <- read_dat("runs/dat/pm_avon2.dat") d2 <- read_dat("runs/dat/std_tune.dat") d3            <- d2 d3$n_avo      <- d1$n_avo d3$ob_avo     <- d1$ob_avo d3$ob_avo_std <- d1$ob_avo_std d3$wt_avo     <- d1$wt_avo d3$yrs_avo    <- d1$yrs_avo  write_dat(output_file="runs/dat/obs_err_tune.dat", indata=d3)  # Files already in "tune" dir file.remove("runs/tune/pm") file.symlink("../../src/pm","runs/tune/pm") # Read pm.dat, then write (e.g.,)   pm.dat<-read_table("runs/tune/pm.dat",col_names=FALSE) # Add some description of the rows...   pm.dat[1,] <- "Obs_error_tuning"   pm.dat[2,] <- "../dat/obs_err_tune.dat"   writeLines(as.character(pm.dat$X1),"runs/tune/pm.dat")

previous_headings: Example use of ebswp library for setting up a new model
what: Now run them all in parallel
title: Example on how to change and run a model
code: mod_dir   <- c("ProcTune","ssb0","ssb1","ssb2")   mod_names <- c("Proc_error_Tune","ssb0","ssb1","ssb2")   # output=TRUE default, also check on spm   res <- run_model()   #res <- get_results()   tab_fit(res, mod_scen = c(1:2)) |> gt::gt()   tab_fit(res, mod_scen = c(1:4)) |> gt::gt()   tab_ref(res, mod_scen = c(1:4)) |> gt::gt() |> gt::fmt_markdown()      # See if different from base   tail(sc2)   ctl <-read_dat("runs/ProcTune/control.dat")   ctlb <-read_dat("runs/base22/control.dat")   diff <- purrr::map_lgl(names(ctl), ~ !identical(ctl[[.]], ctlb[[.]]))   sum(diff)   names(ctl[diff])   cbind(ctl[diff][2],ctlb[diff][2])   names(ctl)   ctl[56]   write_dat("runs/base22/control.dat",ctl)  # Set an initial working directory   mod_names <- c("AVON Full","Proc_tune")   mod_dir <- c("avon2", "ProcTune")   # Note, 0.2 CV for selectivity variability nails it (from base22)   # Read, adjust, write...   sc <-read_table("runs/dat/scmed22P.dat",col_names = FALSE); names(sc) <- c("Year","fsh","bts","ats")   tail(sc )   # Iterated on selectivity   sc2 <-  sc |> mutate(ats = ifelse(ats>0,.138,0))   write.table(sc2,file="runs/dat/scmed22P.dat",col.names = FALSE,row.names = FALSE)   #modtune <- run_model(Output=TRUE)   modtune<-get_results()   tab_fit(modtune, mod_scen = c(1,2)) |> gt::gt()   tab_ref(modtune, mod_scen = c(1,2)) |> gt::gt()   tab_ref(modlst, mod_scen = c(4,5)) |> gt::gt()   (modlst[[4]]$nextyrssbs)   (modlst[[4]]$nextyrssb.sd)   (modtune[[1]]$nextyrssbs)   names(modtune)

title: Application of one-step ahead residuals to alternative EBS pollock model specifications
text: Trijoulet, Vanessa, Christoffer Moesgaard Albertsen, Kasper Kristensen, Christopher M. Legault, Timothy J. Miller, Anders Nielsen. 2023. “Model Validation Compositional Data Stock Assessment Models: Calculating Residuals Correct Properties.” Fisheries Research 257: 106487. https://doi.org/https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fishres.2022.106487.

title: SAFE report front matter
text: Walleye pollock (Gadus chalcogrammus; hereafter referred pollock) broadly distributed throughout North Pacific largest concentrations found Eastern Bering Sea. Also known Alaska pollock, species continues play important roles ecologically economically.

title: SAFE report front matter
text: EBS pollock spawn generally period March-May relatively localized regions specific periods (Bailey 2000). Generally spawning begins nearshore north Unimak Island March April later near Pribilof Islands (Jung et al. 2006, Bacheler et al. 2010). Females batch spawners 10 batches eggs per female per year (peak spawning period). Eggs larvae EBS pollock planktonic period 90 days appear sensitive environmental conditions. conditions likely affect dispersal favorable areas (subsequent separation predators) also affect general food requirements -wintering survival (Gann et al. 2015, Heintz et al., 2013, Hunt et al. 2011, Ciannelli et al. 2004). Duffy-Anderson et al. (2015) provide review early life history EBS pollock. Throughout range juvenile pollock feed variety planktonic crustaceans, including calanoid copepods euphausiids. EBS shelf region, one-year-old pollock found throughout water column, also commonly occur NMFS bottom trawl survey. Ages 2 3 year old pollock rarely caught summer bottom trawl survey gear common midwater zone detected mid-water acoustic trawl surveys. Younger pollock generally found northern parts survey area appear move southeast age (Buckley et al. 2009). Euphausiids, principally Thysanoessa inermis T. raschii, among important prey items pollock Bering Sea (Livingston, 1991; Lang et al., 2000; Brodeur et al., 2002; Cianelli et al., 2004; Lang et al., 2005). Pollock diets become piscivorous age, cannibalism commonly observed region. However, Buckley et al. (2015) showed spatial patterns pollock foraging size predators. example, northern part shelf region 100 200 m isobaths (closest shelf break) tends piscivorous counterparts areas.

title: SAFE report front matter
text: Stock structure EBS pollock evaluated Ianelli et al. (2015). review past work genetics (e.g., Bailey et al. 1999, Canino et al. 2005) provided insight genetic differentiation. investigation also compared synchrony year-classes growth patterns. Pollock samples areas including Zhemchug Canyon, Japan, Prince William Sound, Bogoslof, Shelikof, Northern Bering Sea processed results presented 2021. analysis included 617 walleye pollock Japan, Bering Sea, Chukchi Sea, Aleutian Islands, Alaska Peninsula, Gulf Alaska. Results suggests temporally stable stock structure latitudinal gradient, .e., Bering Sea pollock distinguishable Gulf Alaska Aleutian Islands (. Spies, personal communication, 2021). Notably, Bogoslof samples appeared genetically distinct spawning regions. addition, appeared genetic connectivity eastern Bering Sea western Gulf Alaska spawning samples. Samples eastern Gulf Alaska currently undergoing sequencing determine whether eastern Gulf Alaska pollock genetically distinct western Gulf Alaska. ongoing goals project include investigating genetic stock structure walleye pollock, testing patterns temporally stable, evaluating distributional shifts climate change can detected. management purposes, preliminary conclusions genetics results : 1)stock structure pollock appears stable time 2) aspect stock structure latitudinal—Bering Sea pollock appear distinct fish collected Gulf Alaska Aleutian Islands. results appear strong enough GTseq panel designed future determine stock origin walleye pollock, scale may relatively large, “Bering Sea” “GOA”. scope funding sources project planned 2022 sampling designs developed implementation early 2023.

title: EBS pollock model equations
text: assessment based statistical age-structured model catch equation population dynamics model described Fournier Archibald (1982) elsewhere (e.g., Hilborn Walters 1992, Schnute Richards 1995, McAllister Ianelli 1997). catch numbers age year \(t (C_{t,})\) total catch biomass \((Y_t)\) can described : \[\begin{align}     C_{t,}     &= \frac{F_{t,}}{Z_{t,}} \left(1 - e^{-Z_{t,}}\right) N_{t,}, &1 \le t \le T, 1 \le \le \\     N_{t+1,+1} &= N_{t,-1} e^{-Z_{t,-1}}                                       &1 \le t \le T, 1 \le <   \\     N_{t+1,}   &= N_{t,-1} e^{-Z_{t,-1}} + N_{t,} e^{-Z_{t,}} ,              &1 \le t \le T                \\     Z_{t,}     &= F_{t,} + M_{t,}                                                                            \\     C_{t,.}     &= \sum_{=1}^{C_{t,}}                                                                        \\     p_{t,}     &= \frac{C_{t,} } {C_{t,.} }                                                                   \\     Y_{t}       &= \sum_{=1}^{w_{t,}C_{t,}}                                                                 \\ \end{align}\] Fishing mortality (\(F_{t,}\)) specified semi-separable non-parametric form restrictions variability following Butterworth et al. (2003): \[\begin{align}     F_{t,}     &= s_{t,} \, \mu^f e^{\epsilon_t}, &\epsilon_t   \sim \mathcal{N}(0,\,\sigma_E^{2}) \\     s_{t+1,}   &= s_{t,} \,       e^{\gamma_t},   &\gamma_t     \sim \mathcal{N}(0,\,\sigma_s^{2}) \end{align}\] \(s_{t,}\) selectivity age class \(\) year \(t\), \(\mu^f\) median fishing mortality rate time. selectivities (\(s_{t,}\)) constant time fishing mortality rate decomposes age component year component. curvature penalty selectivity coefficients using squared second-differences provide smoothness ages. Bottom-trawl survey selectivity set asymptotic yet retain properties desired characteristics gear. Namely, function allow flexibility selecting age 1 pollock time. functional form selectivity : \[\begin{align}     s_{t,}     &= \left[ 1+e^{-\alpha_ta-\beta_t} \right]^{-1} , & >1 \\     s_{t,}     &= \mu_se^{-\delta^\mu_t},                        & =1 \\     \alpha_{t}  &= \bar \alpha e^{\delta^\alpha_t},                     \\     \beta_{t}  &= \bar \beta e^{\delta^\beta_t},                         \end{align}\] parameters selectivity function follow random walk process Dorn et al. (2000): \[\begin{align}     \delta_t^\mu  -  \delta_{t+1}^\mu     &\sim \mathcal{N}(0,\,\sigma_{\delta^\mu}^{2}) \\     \\     \alpha_t^\mu  -  \alpha_{t+1}^\mu     &\sim \mathcal{N}(0,\,\sigma_{\alpha^\mu}^{2}) \\     \beta_t^\mu  -  \beta_{t+1}^\mu     &\sim \mathcal{N}(0,\,\sigma_{\beta^\mu}^{2}) \end{align}\] parameters estimated part model thus t=1982 2022. variance terms process error parameters specified 0.04. assessment, random-walk deviation penalty optionally shifted changes log-selectivity. , BTS estimates, process error applied logistic parameters , lognormal penalty applied resulting selectivities--age directly. extent variability evaluated context impact age-specific survey catchability/availability contrasted independent estimate pollock availability bottom trawl survey. \[\begin{align}     {ln(s_{t,})}  -  {ln(s_{t+1,})}  &\sim \mathcal{N}(0,\,\sigma_{sel}^{2}) \\ \end{align}\] 2008 survey selectivity approach modified. option, age one pollock observed trawl can treated index considered part age composition (ranges age 2-15). done improve interaction flexible selectivity smoother used gear compared. Additionally, annual specification input observation variance terms allowed data. diagnostic approach evaluate input variance specifications (via sample size multinomial assumptions) added 2018 assessment. method uses residuals mean ages together concept sample variance mean age (given annual data set) varies inversely input sample size. can shown given set input proportions age (maximum age \(\)) sample size \(N_t\) year \(t\), adjustment factor \(\nu\) input sample size can computed compared assessment model predicted proportions age (\(\hat p_{ta}\)) model predicted mean age (\(\hat{\bar{a_t}}\)): \[\begin{align} \nu   &= \text{var}\left( r^a_t \sqrt{\frac{N_t}{\kappa_t} }\right)^{-1} \\ r^a_t &= \bar a_t - \hat{\bar{a_t}}                                      \\ \kappa_t &= \left[ \sum_a^{\bar a_t - \hat{\bar{a_t}}} \right]^{0.5} \end{align}\] \(r^a_t\) residual mean age \[\begin{align} \hat{\bar{a_t}} &= \sum_a^{\hat p_{ta}}\, \\ {\bar a_t}      &= \sum_a^{p_{ta}}\, \end{align}\] Based previous analyses, used relationship diagnostic evaluating input sample sizes comparing model predicted mean ages observed mean ages implied 95% confidence bands. method provided support modifying frequency allowing selectivity changes.

title: EBS pollock model equations
text: analyses, recruitment (\(R_t\)) represents numbers age-1 individuals modeled stochastic function spawning stock biomass. \[\begin{align}         R_t = f\left(B_{t-1} \right) \end{align}\] mature spawning biomass year \(t\) defined : \[\begin{align}   B_t = \sum_{=1}^{ w_{t,}\phi_aN_{t,}} \end{align}\] , \(\phi_a\) proportion mature females age shown sub-section titled Natural mortality maturity age “Parameters estimated independently” . reparameterized form stock-recruitment relationship following Francis (1992) used. optional Beverton-Holt form (Ricker form presented Eq. 12 adopted assessment) : \[\begin{align} R_t &= \frac{B_{t-1}e^{\varepsilon_t} }{\alpha+\beta B_{t-1} } \end{align}\] Values stock-recruitment function parameters calculated values (number 0-year-olds absence exploitation recruitment variability) steepness stock-recruit relationship (\(h\)). steepness fraction R0 expected (absence recruitment variability) mature biomass reduced 20% pristine level (Francis 1992), : \[\begin{align} \alpha &= \tilde B_0 \frac{1-h}{4h} \\ \beta &= \frac{5h-1}{4hR_0 } \end{align}\] \(\tilde B_0\) total egg production (proxy, e.g., female spawning biomass) absence exploitation (recruitment variability) expressed fraction \(R_0\). interpretation explanation follows. steepness equal 0.2, recruits linear function spawning biomass (implying surplus production). steepness equal 1.0, recruitment constant levels spawning stock size. value \(h = 0.9\) implies 20% unfished spawning stock size result expected value 90% unfished recruitment level. Steepness 0.7 commonly assumed default value Beverton-Holt form (e.g., Kimura 1988). prior distribution steepness used beta distribution Ianelli et al. (2016). prior steepness specified symmetric form Beta distribution \(\alpha = \beta = 14.93\) implying prior mean 0.5 CV 12% (implying 14% chance steepness greater 0.6). conservative prior consistent previous years’ application serves constrain stock-recruitment curve favoring steep slopes (uninformative priors result \(F_{MSY}\) values near \(F_{SPR}\) \(F_{18\%}\) value considerably higher default proxy \(F_{35\%}\)). residual pattern post-1977 recruits used fitting curve diffuse prior resulted estimated recruits curve stock sizes less \(B_{MSY}\) (except 1978 year class). believe driven primarily apparent negative-slope recruits relative stock sizes \(B_{MSY}\) , provides potentially unrealistic estimate productivity low stock sizes. prior elicited rationale residuals reasonably balanced throughout range spawning stock sizes. Whereas somewhat circular (.e., using data prior elicitation), point residual patterns (typically ignored types models) qualitatively considered. model 16.1 (2019 assessment), Beverton Holt stock recruitment form implemented using prior value 0.67 steepness CV 0.17. resulted beta distribution parameters (prior) \(\alpha = 6.339\) \(\beta = 4.293\). value \(\sigma_R\) set 1.0 accommodate additional uncertainty factors affecting recruitment variability. critical value stock-recruitment function (steepness, h) scale Ricker model, begin parameterization Kimura (1990): \[\begin{align} R_t &= \frac{B_{t-1}e^{\alpha \left(1-B_{t-1} \frac{R_0}{\psi_0} \right)}}{\psi_0} \end{align}\] can shown Ricker parameter maps steepness : \[\begin{align} h &= \frac{e^\alpha}{e^\alpha+4} \end{align}\] prior used h can implemented Ricker Beverton-Holt stock-recruitment forms. term \(\psi_0\) represents equilibrium unfished spawning biomass per-recruit.

title: EBS pollock model equations
text: objective function simply sum negative log-likelihood function logs prior distributions. fit large numbers parameters nonlinear models useful able estimate certain parameters different stages. ability estimate stages also important using robust likelihood functions since often undesirable use robust objective functions models far solution. Consequently, early stages estimation use following log- likelihood function survey fishery catch age data (numbers): \[\begin{align} nll() &= n \sum_{t,}{ p_{ta} \ln \hat p_{ta} } \\ p_{ta} &= \frac{O_{ta}}{\sum_a{O_{ta}}} \hspace{20pt} \hat p_{ta} = \frac{\hat C_{ta}}{\sum_a{\hat C_{ta}}} \\ \mathbf{C} &= \mathbf{CE}  \\ \mathbf{E}  &=  \begin{array}{llll} b_{1,1} & b_{1,2} & \dots & b_{1,15} \\ b_{2,1} & b_{2,2} &       & b_{2,15} \\ \vdots &         & \ddots &  \vdots \\ b_{15,1} & b_{15,2} & \dots      & b_{15,15} \end{array}   \end{align}\] \(\), \(T\), represent number age classes years, respectively, n sample size, represent observed predicted numbers age catch. elements bi,j represent ageing mis-classification proportions based independent agreement rates otolith age readers. models presented year, option including aging errors re-evaluated. Sample size values revised shown main document. Strictly speaking, amount data collected fishery indicates higher values might warranted. However, standard multinomial sampling process robust violations assumptions (Fournier et al. 1990). Consequently, model fit approached solution, invoke robust likelihood function fit proportions age : \[\begin{align} \prod_{=1}^\prod_{t=1}^T \left[\left( \exp{\left(-\frac{\left(p_{ta}-\hat p_{ta}\right)^2}{2\left(\eta_{ta}+0.1/\right)\tau_t^2} \right) }+0.01 \right) \times  \frac{1}{ {\sqrt{2\pi \left ( \eta_{ta}+0.1/\right) \tau_t}} } \right] \end{align}\] Taking logarithm obtain log-likelihood function age composition data: \[\begin{align} nll() = -0.5\sum_{=1}^\sum_{t=1}^T{ {\ln{2\pi \left( \eta_{ta}+0.1/\right) -\sum_t^T \ln\tau_t}} } +\sum_{=1}^\sum_{t=1}^T{\ln\left\{ \exp{\left(-\frac{\left(p_{ta}-\hat p_{ta}\right)^2}{\left(2\eta_{ta}+0.1/\right)\tau_t^2} \right) + 0.01 } \right\}} \end{align}\] \[\begin{align} \eta_{ta} &=  p_{ta}(1-p_{ta})\\ \text{} \\ \tau_t^2 &=  1/n_t \end{align}\] gives variance \(p_{ta}\) \[\begin{align} (\eta_{ta}+0.1/)\tau_t^2 \end{align}\] Completing estimation fashion reduces model sensitivity data otherwise considered outliers. Within model, predicted survey abundance accounted within-year mortality since surveys occur middle year. previous years, assumed removals survey insignificant (.e., mortality pollock caused survey considered insignificant). Consequently, set analogous catchability selectivity terms estimated fitting survey observations : \[\begin{align} \hat N_{ta}^s &= e^{-0.5Z_{ta}}N_{ta}q_t^ss_{ta}^S \end{align}\] superscript s indexes type survey (BTS). option use survey predictions biomass terms instead just abundance, modified include observed survey biomass weights--age: \[\begin{align} \hat N_{ta}^s &= e^{-0.5Z_{ta}}w_{ta}N_{ta}q_t^ss_{ta}^S \end{align}\] AVO index, values selectivity assumed survey mean weights age time also assumed equal values estimated survey. analyses chose keep survey catchabilities constant time (though estimated separately AVO index bottom trawl surveys). contribution negative log-likelihood function (ignoring constants) surveys given either lognormal distribution: \[\begin{align} nll() &= \sum_t{\frac{\ln(u_t^s/\hat N_t^s)^2}{2\sigma_{s,t}^2}} \end{align}\] \(u_t^s\) total (numerical abundance optionally biomass) estimate variance \(\sigma_{s,t}\) survey \(s\) year \(t\) optionally, normal distribution can selected: \[\begin{align} nll() &= \sum_t{\frac{(u_t^s - \hat N_t^s)^2}{2\sigma_{s,t}^2}}. \\ \end{align}\] survey AVO index modeled using lognormal distribution whereas BTS survey, normal distribution applied. model configurations BTS data corrected estimated efficiency, multivariate lognormal distribution used. negative- log likelihood component modeled \[\begin{equation} nll_i = 0.5\mathbf{X}\Sigma^{-1}\mathbf{X}^{'} \end{equation}\] vector observed minus model predicted values index \(\Sigma\) estimated covariance matrix provided method provided Kotwicki et al. 2014. VAST estimates, supplied covariance matrix used way. contribution negative log-likelihood function observed total catch biomass (\(C_b^{obs}, \hat{C_b}\)) fishery given \[\begin{equation} nll_i = 0.5\sum_t\frac{\ln(C_b^{obs}/\hat C_b)^2}{2\sigma_{C_b,t}^2} \end{equation}\] \(\sigma_{C_b,t}\) pre-specified (set 0.05) reflecting accuracy overall observed catch biomass. Similarly, contribution prior distributions (negative log-density) log-likelihood function include \(\lambda_\varepsilon \sum_t\varepsilon_t^2 +\lambda_\gamma \sum_{ta}\gamma^2 + \lambda_\delta \sum_t\delta_t^2\) size ’s represent prior assumptions variances random variables. parameters associated year-- year age specific deviations selectivity coefficients. presentation type Bayesian approach modeling errors-- variables, reader referred Schnute (1994). facilitate estimating large number parameters, automatic differentiation software extended Greiwank Corliss (1991) developed C++ class libraries used. software provided derivative calculations needed finding posterior mode via quasi-Newton function minimization routine (e.g., Press et al. 1992). model implementation language (ADModel Builder) gave simple rapid access routines provided ability estimate variance-covariance matrix dependent independent parameters interest.

title: EBS pollock model equations
text: approach use solve \(F_{MSY}\) related quantities (e.g., \(B_{MSY}\) \(MSY\)) within general integrated model context shown Ianelli et al. (2001). 2007 modified include uncertainty weight--age explicit part uncertainty \(F_{MSY}\) calculations. involved estimating vector parameters (\(w_{ta}^{future}\)) current (2022) future mean weights age \(\), \(\)= (1, 2,…,15), given actual observed mean variances weight--age period 1991-2021. values based available data (option selected) estimates parameters subject natural constraint: \[w_{ta}^{future} \sim \mathcal{N}(\bar{w_{}},\,\sigma_{w_a}^{2})\] Note converges mean values time series data (likelihood component within model affected future mean weights--age) retaining natural uncertainty can propagate estimates \(F_{MSY}\) uncertainty. latter point essentially requirement Tier 1 categorization. Subsequently, method refined account current-year survey data cohort year effects. model : \[\begin{align} \hat{w}_{ta} &= \bar w_a e^{\upsilon_t} & =1, \, t \ge 1964 \\ \hat{w}_{ta} &= \hat{w}_{t-1,-1} + \Delta_a e^{\psi_t} & > 1, \, t > 1964 \\ \Delta_a     &= \bar w_{+1} - \bar w_a & < \\ \bar w_a     &= \alpha \left\{L_1+ \left(L_2-L_1\right)\left(\frac{1-K^{-1}}{1-K^{-1}}\right)\right\}^3  \\ \end{align}\] fixed effects parameters \(L_1, L_2, K,\) \(\alpha\) random effects parameters \(\upsilon_t\) \(\psi_t\).

title: EBS pollock model equations
text: Tier 1 projections calculated two ways. First, 2023 2024 ABC \(OFL\) levels, harmonic mean \(F_{MSY}\) value computed analogous harvest rate (\(\bar{u_{HM}}\)) applied estimated geometric mean fishable biomass \(B_{MSY}\) : \[\begin{align} ABC_t &= B_{GM,t}^f \hat{u}_{HM}\zeta_t \\ B_{GM,t}^f &= e^{\ln{\hat{B}_t^f}-0.5\sigma_{B^f}^2} \\ u_{HM,t}^f &= e^{\ln{\hat{u}_{MSY,t}}-0.5\sigma_{u_{MSY}}^2} \\ \zeta_{t} &= \frac{B_t/B_{MSY}-0.05}{1-0.05} & B_t < B_{MSY} \\ \zeta_{t} &= 1.0 & B_t \ge  B_{MSY} \end{align}\] \(\hat{B}_t^f\) point estimate fishable biomass defined (given year): \(\sum_a{N_as_{ta}w_{ta}}\) \(N_{ta}\), \(s_{ta}\), \(w_{ta}\) estimated population numbers (begin year), selectivity weights--age, respectively. \(B_{MSY}\) \(B_{t}\) point estimates spawning biomass levels equilibrium \(F_{MSY}\) year \(t\) (time spawning). projections, catch must specified (solved current year \(B_t < B_{MSY}\)). longer term projections form operating model (presented evaluation \(B_{20\%}\)) feedback (via future catch specifications) using control rule assessment model required.

what: Facilitates Model Running for EBS Pollock
title: Facilitates Model Running for EBS Pollock
text: R package ebswp developed stock assessments eastern Bering Sea walleye pollock AFSC. stock assessment model coded using Autodif Model Builder (ADMB) software.

title: Facilitates Model Running for EBS Pollock
text: R package ebswp lives private GitHub repository. repository can cloned computer command line using user interface. command line using Linux repository can cloned using:

title: Facilitates Model Running for EBS Pollock
text: several options installing ebswp R package.

title: Facilitates Model Running for EBS Pollock
text: ebswp package can installed within R using:
code: devtools::install_github(repo = "afsc-assessments/ebswp", dependencies = TRUE,                           build_vignettes = TRUE, auth_token = "your_PAT")

title: Facilitates Model Running for EBS Pollock
text: GitHub repository can cloned computer package installed command line. Linux involve:
code: git clone https://github.com/afsc-assessments/ebswp R CMD INSTALL ebswp

title: Age Composition Data Plotter — plot_agefit

title: Age Composition Data Plotter — plot_agefit
text: case_label Label specific case dataset visualized. Default "2011 assessment". dat data frame, default mod1. structure must contain age composition data, names used create temporary variables tmp1, tmp2, tmp3. main Title main plot. Default empty string. f integer representing fishery index. Default 1. rec_age integer denoting recruitment age. Default 2.

title: Age Composition Data Plotter — plot_agefit
text: multi-panel plot panel visualizes age composition data specific year.

text: function uses rainbow color palette, colors loop around cohort. function expects certain naming conventions input dataset dat.

Default NULL. coverlap Logical, TRUE overlapping text labels checked prevented. Default FALSE. sizein Font size -sample text labels. Default 3. sizeout Font size --sample text labels. title: Rescale a Covariance Matrix — rescale_cov
text: function rescales covariance matrix using either Cholesky decomposition method simple diagonal adjustment.

title: Rescale a Covariance Matrix — rescale_cov
text: Sigma covariance matrix needs rescaled. Scale_factor numeric value vector used scaling. DoChol Logical indicating Cholesky decomposition method used. FALSE, simple diagonal adjustment method used. Default FALSE.

title: Rescale a Covariance Matrix — rescale_cov
text: rescaled covariance matrix.

what: Run Multiple ADMB Models in Parallel — run_model
title: Run Multiple ADMB Models in Parallel — run_model
text: function uses parallel processing run multiple ADMB models gather outputs. running models, also fetches certain variables 'proj/spm_detail.csv' file associated model.

title: Run Multiple ADMB Models in Parallel — run_model
code: run_model(moddir = mod_dir, modnames = mod_names, Output = TRUE)

title: Run Multiple ADMB Models in Parallel — run_model
text: moddir Character vector. directory paths models, default mod_dir. modnames Character vector. names models, default mod_names. Output Logical. flag indicating output displayed (e.g., messages, progress, etc.), default FALSE.

title: Run Multiple ADMB Models in Parallel — run_model
text: list containing outputs ADMB models fetched variables.

what: Write Data to Text File — write_dat
title: Write Data to Text File — write_dat
text: function takes list data elements (matrices, vectors, values) writes specified text file. data element list preceded comment line indicating name.

title: Write Data to Text File — write_dat
Write Data to Text File — write_dat
text: output_file character string specifying name output text file. Default "output.txt". indata list containing data elements written file. element can matrix, vector, value. Default in_data.

title: Write Data to Text File — write_dat
text: function return value; writes specified output file.

title: Write Data to Text File — write_dat
code: # Assuming 'data_list' is a list of data elements # write_dat(output_file = "sample_output.txt", indata = data_list)
